nodes.text:
Copy and Fax Room smells of hot plastic and old staples. (pause)
The fax machine is idle. The kind of idle that stays warm. (pause)
In the tray: a curled half-fed printout. (pause)
Legal’s Work Order, rendered in exhausted ink. Half text, half ghosts.

choices.text: use: Pull the pages from the tray.
use: Re-run the fax until the Work Order is legible (and make a duplicate).
look: Check the header and routing line.
show: Use a service code sticker to adjust print density.
leave: Step away.

nodes.text:
The top page is a Work Order template—half text, half afterimage. (pause)
The signature block is present. (pause)
The scope paragraph is not. (pause)
It’s enough to start an argument. (pause)
Not enough to end one.

choices.text: use: Re-run the fax until it’s legible.
look: Check the header and routing line again.
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Keep the bad copy and move on.

nodes.text:
The header line prints in blocky, exhausted characters: (pause)
ROUTE: OLEA LEGAL — OUTBOUND / DEST: FACILITY FAX (POSTED) (pause)
REF: WO-RET-SP01 (pause)
The timestamp is five minutes ago. (pause)
The machine is still warm, like it wants credit.

choices.text: use: Re-run the fax until the Work Order is legible (and make a duplicate).
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Step away.

nodes.text: Run it again. Two clean sets.

The fax machine wakes up with a complaint disguised as a motor. (pause)

Page one prints crisp at the top and dissolves in the middle. (pause)
Page two prints the middle perfectly and sacrifices the asset line to a smear.

choices.text: use: Re-run again.
show: Use a service code sticker to adjust print density.
look: Compare the best lines and assemble a “most legible” set.
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Stop here. It’s “good enough.”

nodes.text: The machine tries a new failure mode. (pause) This time the header line is perfect. (pause) The signature is a bruise. (pause) Legal’s name is readable. (pause) But the pen stroke looks like it was done while bracing for impact.

choices.text: use: Re-run until you have two fully legible sets.
look: Keep the cleanest lines and stop.
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Give up for now.

nodes.text:
You lay the pages out and select sentences like you’re building a body from acceptable parts. (pause)

What you end up with reads like a fence built out of clauses: (pause)

“WORK ORDER — RETIREMENT SUPPORT (NARROW PURPOSE)” (pause)

“ASSET: SP-01 (as labeled on site)” (pause)

“SCOPE: Closure-support activities limited to verification and documentation steps listed on the standard retirement checklist.” (pause)

“EXCLUSIONS: No exploratory testing. No evaluation of anomalous conditions. No language implying ‘authorization to enter.’” (pause)

“THIS INSTRUMENT CONFIRMS TASK DESCRIPTION ONLY.” (pause)

“It does not certify site condition, personnel training, or safety baseline.” (pause)

The last line is underlined twice like someone pressed too hard.

choices.text: use: Re-run until you have two fully legible pages each.
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Take the patched set and move on.

nodes.text: The sticker peels reluctantly like it was saving itself for an emergency that mattered. (pause) You key in a code that should not be common knowledge. (pause) The machine accepts it without comment. (pause) The silence is a comment. (pause) The next print is darker. (pause) The words stop trying to disappear.

choices.text: use: Print a duplicate set for the closure binder.
look: Read the scope language carefully.
ask: Back to the tray options.
leave: Stop after one set.

nodes.text: The scope language is narrow enough to fit through a mail slot. (pause) Every helpful noun is paired with an unhelpful disclaimer, (pause) like Legal is stapling you to the document at a safe distance.

choices.text: use: Print a duplicate set for the closure binder.
ask: Back.
leave: Pocket it and go.

nodes.text:
You reach for the “right numbers” and come up short. (pause)

Either you don’t have the sticker (pause)
or you don’t have the procedure down clean enough to risk it. (pause)

The machine keeps its bland, default contrast—perfect for receipts and terrible for liability.

On the next passes the printer finally commits to ink. (pause)
You get two legible Work Order pages. (pause)
They are duplicates with edges still warm. (pause)
They match each other. An institutional miracle. (pause)
The machine keeps its faint mechanical hum a second too long. (pause)
As if it is waiting for you to ask it to certify something.
You fold the pages anyway. The fold goes through the only readable sentence.
You can already hear an auditor saying “good enough” like it’s profanity.
You keep the best of the damage. The binder will have to forgive you.
You fold it carefully (pause) avoiding the clean paragraph like it’s a wound. (pause) One set isn’t a binder. (pause) It’s a promise you haven’t backed up yet.
